children.subject: the 5th year's is really cheap (relatively)! it's the same price as your undergraduate tuition. so if you're in state, that's potentially a steal for a masters

also: (1) some jobs "require" advanced degrees, (2) to take advanced coursework in areas of your interest (i.e. if you're super into systems, AI/ML, etc., you could potentially go very deep with graduate level coursework), (3) work on a substantial research project which may be useful if you're thinking about a phd at some point
those all sound like reasons to do a PhD though. why wouldn't you just apply for a PhD directly?

• compare the duration: 1 year cf. 3-6 years
  • further, compare opportunity cost of 1 year not in industry to 3-6 years not in industry
  • compare paying out of pocket ("cheap") to phd funding
  • your competitiveness for a phd program vs. the 5th year ms program could be really different
  • different interests. phd = almost purely research, with classes maybe the first year or two. ms = additional year of courses + one year long research project. (do you want to research something theoretical/abstract, or would you rather just get some experience and then move into industry?)
    • again, from what i understand, the 5th year ms can serve either as a terminal degree if you're going into industry, or it can be a stepping stone for some applicants who feel that they don't have a good research background / competitive chances for phd programs

These reasons are sound, but PhDs are often stipened by the department, so it's mostly free (except for the time cost). But in that regard, should you decide that PhD life is not for you, you have the option of terminating your PhD early to instead get a master. So it seems like the only reason you should apply for a masters is if you don't feel like you are currently a good fit for a PhD program, and need some more research experience / published papers under your belt?

Sorry yeah, bullet point #3 doesn't really matter. It's mostly #2 that is a huge (i.e. $150k+ salary/stock per year vs. minimal living stipend, for many situations.)

And yes, you can definitely terminate you PhD early -- it's a (not so secret / questionable) technique that people do to get a "free masters" (since, as you've said, you should be able to get funding initially for your PhD program, then you drop out --> free masters). 

I think it boils down to: what you said about being a competitive applicant, potential opportunity cost (+ promotion opportunities! this is financially huge over the span of 3-6 years), whether you want an advanced degree for research/academic purposes, or for (industry) career-furthering purposes?

Also note that there's absolutely nothing preventing you from applying to be the 5th years + PhD programs.

would you say that it's easier to get into a masters than it is to get in to a PhD program? what are they looking for that is different? it seems like for both programs, you need a solid academic background and interest in research. so why would you be accepted into masters but not PhD?
thanks for hashing this out with me by the way. i haven't yet looked into it but it's on my mind, so it's really good to hear from someone more experienced

genuine question: why are you applying? from what i hear, starting salaries are pretty much equivalent for BA/BS and Masters students in EECS, and the program is pretty expensive. So what are the pros?

history.content:
Hi there, 

I'm not the Adviser for this program (see Michael in 205 Cory), but did view some apps this year. I don't think we considered any undergraduates without research experience, in part because it's very difficult to have strong faculty letters of recommendation if you haven't worked in their lab(s).

children.subject:
As a note, there are two programs: the M.Eng: http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/MEng/index.shtml

and the 5th year masters: https://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/FiveYearMS/

Each has a different focus.

Does the instructor mean that without research experience, applying for MENG is also nearly impossible? I am not really interested in research. If that's the case, I will consider giving up on graduate school.

history.content:
How necessary is research experience to get into the MEng one year Master's degree program, if I have several summers of industry experience and meet the other recommended requirements (GPA, GRE)?

Also, in general, how difficult is it to get into?
history.subject: Master of Engineering One Year Program
